automation_test.title: ğŸ—ƒ How do I test my Automation? ğŸ§°
automation_test.description:
To test an automation there's three stages you can follow. Testing the action, the condition and action, and the whole automation:

1) Use _Configuration_ -> _Automations_ to find the automation and then push _Run Actions_. If this fails your problem is in the `action:` section, and details should be found in your log file
2) Use _Developer tools_ -> _Services_ and call `automation.trigger` on the automation with `skip_condition: false`. If the first passes but this fails then the problem is in your `condition:` block
3) Use _Developer tools_ -> _States_ to find the trigger entity, click the name, then change the state (at the top) to something that'll trigger the automation before pushing _Set State_. If this fails then the problem is with your `trigger:` section, or the automation is turned off (you can check that in _Developer tools -> States_).

You can also see [this section in the docs](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/automation/troubleshooting/) and with HA 2021.4 onwards [debug automations](https://www.home-assistant.io/blog/2021/04/07/release-20214/#automation-debugging).

avatar.title: Avatar
avatar.description:
Here on DrZzs Discord we would like everyone to have a good experience.  We strongly encourage you to pick an avatar that reflects you and not continue to use the default Clyde icon. 
ğŸ”¸ First find a small picture that you like and that you want to represent you. 
ğŸ”¸ Click the gear next to your name near the bottom of the page. 
ğŸ”¸ Hover over the icon and click it. 
ğŸ”¸ Select your new picture file here. 
ğŸ”¸ Save it and pop back and it will appear!

backup.title: Home Assistant Backup ğŸªƒ
backup.description: Be sure to regularly, automatically, back up your Home Assistant install. There are various critical files and configuration options (like the Z-Wave network key), plus all your time. Hass.io has snapshots, and for unix type installs see <https://blog.ceard.tech/2017/10/backing-up-home-assistant.html>.  Oh, and most important of all **test your ability to restore regularly**.

deconz.title: deCONZ - ConBee/RaspBee Zigbee gateway
deconz.description:
Deconz and the Phoscon Web App can be installed in Docker, within Home Assistant as an addon, or can even be bought as part of a hardware solution preinstalled on a dedicated Raspberry Pi.  

ğŸ [Phoscon's ConBee Stick Page](https://phoscon.de/en/conbee/software)  

Deconz, by Phoscon (the makers of the ConbeeII Zigbee USB stick) is a central hub for the integration of Zigbee devices.  The default installation includes the Deconz app as well the Phsocon web app for controlling devices from a browser.  aWhile the software can be used as a standalone app it is also available as a Home Assistant Addon.  With the ConbeeII stick and Deconz, you can take control of any Hue devices you already have or add new ones without using a Hue hub.  The software also support the Phoscon RaspBee and RaspBee II Pi hat devices.

discord_fonts.title: Displaying Emoji's in Discord using Linux
discord_fonts.description:
If the icons next to names and reactions in Discord are showing as empty boxes or  mono color, try this.  
Install the font, in Debian this is the command:  

```sudo apt update;sudo apt install fonts-noto-color-emoji -y```

[Then follow the instructions on this page...](<https://victor.kropp.name/blog/emoji-on-linux/>)

esp32.title: ESP32 from Expressif
esp32.description:
It should be known that some ESP chips do not come with soldered pins, So soldering may be required.  

ğŸ—ƒ [ExpressIF' ESP32 Homepage](https://www.espressif.com/en/products/socs/esp32/overview)  
ğŸ—ƒ [ESP32 WIKI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESP32)  
ğŸ—ƒ [Buy HiLetgo ESP-WROOM-32 ESP32](https://tinyurl.com/yb664res)  
ğŸ—ƒ [Buy Adafruit HUZZAH32 â€“ ESP32 Feather Board](https://www.adafruit.com/product/3405)  
ğŸ—ƒ [Buy SparkFun ESP32 Thing](https://www.sparkfun.com/products/13907)  
ğŸ—ƒ [ESP32 from QuinLED](https://drzzs.com/shop/quinled-esp32/)

The ESP32 is a microcontroller with built-in 2.4GHz Wifi (802.11b/g/n) and Bluetooth (Classic and BLE) made by a company called Espressif.  It comes in several flavors, each one with its own part number, but most people refer them collectively as 'ESP32'.

It was created as a successor to the wildly popular ESP8266, and has many more pins and available on-board functions, such as Bluetooth, Capacitive Touch, Analog Pins (both ADC and DAC), PWM, I2C, I2S, SPI, and many others.  While they are more expensive than the ESP8266-based chips and boards, the ESP32 is still a good value for any projects requiring many inputs or outputs, bluetooth connectivity, or sensor integration.

Generally, we only recommend the bare chips for advanced users who are designing their own circuit boards.  If you are looking to include one in your project, there are many options for pre-built development boards that have everything you'll need for a successful integration.  Please see the links for board options.

esp8266.title: ESP8255 from Expressif
esp8266.description:
It should be known that some ESP chips do not come with soldered pins, So soldering may be required.  

ğŸ—ƒ [ESP8266 ExpressIF Homepage](https://www.espressif.com/en/products/socs/esp8266/overview)  
ğŸ—ƒ [ESP8266 WIKI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESP8266)  
ğŸ—ƒ [Buy KeeYees ESP8266 NodeMCU](https://tinyurl.com/yal4c3a4)  
ğŸ—ƒ [Buy TeOhk D1 Mini](https://tinyurl.com/yalstq77)  
ğŸ—ƒ [Buy Adafruit Feather HUZZAH with ESP8266](https://www.adafruit.com/product/2821)  
ğŸ—ƒ [Buy SparkFun ESP8266 Thing](https://www.sparkfun.com/products/13231)  

The ESP8266 is a microcontroller with built-in 2.4GHz Wifi (802.11b/g/n) made by a company called Espressif.  It comes in several flavors, each one with its own part number, but most people refer them collectively as 'ESP8266'.

It was originally designed and released as a wifi bridge to be used in conjunction with other microcontrollers and was initially released with only 8 pins exposed on a module known as an ESP-01.  It is super cheap, and when everyone realized that it was much more capable than being just a wifi bridge, people started using it in projects and products.  Espressif heard about what was being done with their chips and started releasing different modules with all of the pins exposed.

There aren't very many pins, though, and some of them are a bit... quirky to use.  But, because they're cheap, many smart home gadget companies started using them as the main chip in their products.  (Sonoff, Shelly, and Tuya being three you'll see thrown around in here.)

Generally, we only recommend the bare chips for advanced users who are designing their own circuit boards.  If you are looking to include one in your project, there are many options for pre-built development boards that have everything you'll need for a successful integration. Please see the links for board options.

esphome.title: ESPHome from Home Assistant
esphome.description:
ESPHome may be installed in Home Assistant as a supervisor add-on, or as a standalone installation.  Standalone install instructions can be found at ğŸ—¿ https://esphome.io/guides/getting_started_command_line.html  

ğŸ—¿ [ESPHome's Homepage](https://esphome.io)  

ESPHome provides a simple way to configure code to run on your (ESP8266 or ESP32 based) wireless devices.  These devices include the Sonoff range of wifi controllable products, along with many others.  The software is configured using YAML files with a very simple syntax.  Don't let that fool you though.  The resulting software can be very powerful, and can be used to set up devices for direct integration with Home Assistant without the need for an MQTT broker as with Tasmota.

group.title: HA Groups
group.description: Groups allow the user to combine multiple entities into one, and create views in the default dashboard. See <https://home-assistant.io/components/group/> for information.

ha_supervised.title: Setting up HA Supervised
ha_supervised.description:
Home Assistant Supervised can be installed on top of Docker on any generic linux system, a Debian based system is recommended. Below you will find links to tutorials and resources. 

ğŸ  [Matheson's Install HA Supervised on Debian](https://mathesonsteplock.ca/install-home-assistant-supervised-on-debian/) 
ğŸ  [JuanMTech's Home Assistant on Docker and Ubuntu](https://youtu.be/ekVfLXnoM7k) 
ğŸ  [HA Supervised Installer](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervised-installer) 
ğŸ  [Install Docker Engine](https://docs.docker.com/engine/install/) 

Home Assistant (Supervised) is the version of Home Assistant which runs the Home Assistant Supervisor. 

The supervisor is is a container that runs in Docker which allows the use of Add-ons and manages updating and other maintenance of your Home Assistant Install. 

With the help of the generic Linux install script you can install Home Assistant (Supervised) on any Linux System running Docker

input_boolean.title: Input Boolean
input_boolean.description: Input booleans allow an entity to be created to save a toggleable state.  You can find more about them here: [More information](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/input_boolean/)

input_number.title: Input Number
input_number.description:
The `input_number` component allows the user to define values that can be controlled via the frontend and can be used within conditions of automation. The frontend can display a slider, or a numeric input box. Changes to the slider or numeric input box generate state events. These state events can be utilized as `automation` triggers as well.
```yaml
# Example configuration.yaml entry
input_number:
  slider1:
    name: Slider
    initial: 30
    min: -20
    max: 35
    step: 1
  box1:
    name: Numeric Input Box
    initial: 30
    min: -20
    max: 35
    step: 1
    mode: box
```
[More information:](https://home-assistant.io/components/input_number/)

led_calc_power.title: ğŸ’« Calculate LED Power
led_calc_power.description:
What is Power Injection? At its lowest level power injection is nothing more than adding additional power to a string of lights at a point in which the voltage drop starts to affect the lights 

ğŸ¦Ÿ [More details here](http://spikerlights.com/pwrinjection.aspx) 

ğŸ¦Ÿ This is a great calculator to help with judging the size of wire, power supplies, distance, votage drop, and much more: [RGB Pixel Power Calculator.](http://spikerlights.com/calcpower.aspx)

ğŸ¦Ÿ Quindor also has compiled tons of info on wire sizing that can be found [here.](https://quinled.info/2018/10/20/wire-thickness-needed/) 

ğŸ¦Ÿ How much power do addressable LEDs use? Quindor's Digitally Addressable LED Sheet can be found [here.](https://quinled.info/2020/03/12/digital-led-power-usage/)

ledflicker.title: ğŸ’« LEDs Flickering?
ledflicker.description:
Having issues with your LEDs flickering? There could be many causes, follow [this](https://drzzs.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/Pixel-Flickering-Algorithm.jpeg) flowchart from DrZzs to troubleshoot your issue. 

 Links referenced: 
 [Data Signal Condtioning](https://quinled.info/data-signal-cable-conditioning/) 
 [QuinLED Data Booster](https://quinled.info/quinled-data-booster-for-sale/) 
 [QuinLED Data Booster Power Injection](https://quinled.info/quinled-data-booster-maxi-power-injection/)

 [DrZzs: How to Fix LED Flickering and Inject Power](https://youtu.be/2_saSAf8hgo)
 [VCS Presention: Why pixels flicker and how to fix it](https://youtu.be/9ttEAyiyTAI)

led_reference.title: ğŸ’« LED Related References
led_reference.description:
**How Do I Use These?**
Just type {prefix} and the reference you would like to display.

**References**
`esp32` - Information About ESP32 Boards
`esp8266` - Information About ESP8266 Boards

`led_flicker` - Help With Flickering LEDs
`led_fm` - FM Radio Station Search
`led_fpp`- Falcon Pi Player Information
`led_hardware` - Hardware Vendors Specializing In LED Products
`led_inject` - Power Injection And Data Boosting Solutions
`led_kulp` - Kulp Light Controllers
`led_prints` - Collection Of 3D Prints For Use With LEDs

mariaDB.title: Help with your Home Assistant Database Issues
mariaDB.description:
Home Assistant comes with a built-in version of SQLite database.  If you suspect a database problem, the home-assistant_v2.DB file in your config folder can be deleted or renamed to disable it.  HA will rebuild it immediately.  I would wait 10 minutes after deleting (or renaming the file before you restart HA to give the file a chance to rebuild. 

ğŸ“– [Official HA Docs on Recorder](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/recorder/) 
ğŸ“– [MariaDB Supervised Addon](https://github.com/home-assistant/hassio-addons/tree/master/mariadb) 
ğŸ“– [WhatAreWeFixing.Today's YT Video](https://whatarewefixing.today/240/) 
ğŸ“– [Official HA Docs on Database](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/backend/database/) 
ğŸ“– [Reddit thread about non-default Databases](https://www.reddit.com/r/homeassistant/comments/9z0tof/) 
ğŸ“– [BurnsHA's YT Video](https://youtu.be/4rsxnN8gkHk) 

The default database that is used to store all recorded data in Home Assistant is SQLite.  As you get into a few dozen devices and hundreds of sensor data points, SQLite causes the occasional database corruption. If your Database file is over 1GB, if you are getting Recorder failures in the log, if sensor data randomly stops displaying in your user interface, it is probably time to purge the database. If this continues to happen to you, it may be time to replace the database with something else.

  The easiest way to replace the database is to use the Official Add-on MariaDB.  This is a mysql based program that can handle larger amounts of data better than the default.  

If you are not running the supervised version of HA, there is a video for you in the links as well.  Also other database solutions will work with Home Assistant, see the link for the recorder integration for more details.

mqtt.title: MQTT: The Standard for IoT Messaging ğŸ–‡
mqtt.description:
To install MQTT with Home Assistant, Check out this link:  ğŸ¡ https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/mqtt/  

ğŸ¡ [MQTT Homepage](http://mqtt.org/)  
ğŸ¡ [MQTT WIKI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MQTT)  
ğŸ¡ [HA Official MQTT Docs](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/mqtt/)  
ğŸ¡ [MQTT-Explorer Homepage](http://mqtt-explorer.com/)  
ğŸ¡ [The Hook Up's MQTT Video](https://tinyurl.com/thehookupmqtt)  

ğŸ‡² ğŸ‡¶ ğŸ‡¹ ğŸ‡¹, or Message Queuing Telemetry Transport, is a light-weight protocol used in many situations where small message size and/or low bandwidth usage are important.  It was developed by IBM in 1999, and was initially used to monitor oil pipeline sensors and communicate with satellites. It became very popular, and is used extensively in SCADA control systems and smarthome products.

MQTT utilizes a central service called a Broker that can be installed on just about any computer or server.  Clients connect to the Broker to monitor and update various Topics.  Subscriber Clients connect to the Broker and monitor a Topic; Publisher Clients connect to the Broker and update a Topic's value.  A Client can fill either role or both.

Home Assistant and other home automation packages fill both roles, as do most Wifi connected smart plugs and devices.

There are libraries available in many programming languages (e.g. Arduino and Python) which can be used in custom sensor applications.

When troubleshooting MQTT issues, it is useful to use a utility such as MQTT Explorer.

mqtt_explorer.title: MQTT Explorer
mqtt_explorer.description:
Troubleshooting ğŸ‡² ğŸ‡¶ ğŸ‡¹ ğŸ‡¹?  Retains hanging you up?  
Can't figure out the topic.  Is this thing *WORKING* â”â“ â”  
This tool will help you be successful!  

  [Click here, and don't let the smile scare you.](http://mqtt-explorer.com/)

neoPixel.title: NEOPixels ğŸš¦ LED Lights etal...
neoPixel.description:
Individually Addressable LEDs come in many varieties; you may find them referred to as NeoPixels, or by their part numbers, which include WS2811, WS2812b, WS2813, WS2815, SK9822, SK9812, or APA106.

You will need a microcontroller of some kind to run them; popular examples are an ESP8266 and ESP32 based board running WLED, like the Dig-Uno and Dig-Quad, or a BeagleBone based board running FPP like a Kulp Controller. 

DrZzs has a lot of great videos!  Check out his LED Playlist to get started:
ğŸš¦ [DrZzs LED YouTube Playlist](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZDQGDmtZ3zY&list=PLL02pNmOcO9kOgJYkwcv4c1ApVffxIN8d)  

See also: 
 {prefix}WLED
 {prefix}LED_Controller

Node-Red is a fantastic flow based visual tool for creating and linking automations and devices.  Node-Red works very well with Home-Assistant to provide a nice easy infrastructure for your wildest dreams.

nodeMCU.title: NodeMcu ğŸ§© Connect Things EASY
nodeMCU.description:

ğŸ§© [NodeMCU WIKI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NodeMCU)  
ğŸ§© [Amazon Buy KeeYees NodeMCU](https://tinyurl.com/yal4c3a4)  

NodeMCU is a popular development board that has an ESP8266 Module on it.  It has a USB port for both power and Serial-to-USB connectivity, as well as duplicate power pins.  It's convenient for adding multiple accessories to because you don't need to deal with splicing the power pins.  Product link is available in the links list.

See also: {prefix}ESP8266

power_over_ethernet.title: PoE - Pass Electric Power over Ethernet
power_over_ethernet.description:
Power Over Ethernet requires a POE capable device (Wifi Hotspot or Camera), as well as a power supply such as a POE Switch or a POE Power injector.  

ğŸ—² [Reference: PoE WIKI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_over_Ethernet)  

Power Over Ethernet is a way to supply power to devices over the network cable from a central point.  It enables us to use electronics where there are no electrical outlets nearby and increases ease of management by having power supplies centrally located for devices in hard-to-reach locations.  

POE comes in three standard flavors:  

1) POE (802.3af) Delivers 15W @ 48V 
2)POE+ (802.3at) Delivers 30W @ 48V
3)POE++ or 4PPoE (802.3bt) Delivers 60W-100W @ 48V (Depending upon type of 802.3bt used)  

Be certain to review the power requirements of any POE Device prior to purchase to ensure that you're getting everything you need.  

POE will work with CAT5e, CAT6, and CAT7. As for non-POE installations, care should be taken to not kink or bed the cable too sharply as it will create problems.  

Devices do not need to have ethernet ports!  There are POE Converters that can go from 48V DC to 5V DC or 12V DC, and can be plugged into ESP Wifi chips, or Single Board Computers.

pull_request.title: Pull Request ğŸ How to contribute in GitHub
pull_request.description:
No installation required.  

ğŸ [HIVE Reference Data Github](https://github.com/Blade2021/HIVE-RefData)  
ğŸ [Creating a Simple Github Pull Request](https://youtu.be/rgbCcBNZcdQ)  
ğŸ [What is Git and Github?](https://youtu.be/uUuTYDg9XoI  

A pull request is a part of GIT workflow.  Developers collaborate on pieces of a project then when ready to update the master file, they submit pull requests to allow other developers in most cases, to review, adjust, and then commit the changes to the master file.  This allows multiple developers to work simultaneously on the same project without conflict in most cases.

With the HIVE-References project, we are accepting submissions from anyone and everyone.  Be sure to check out repo in the links section.

rf433.title: ğŸ“¡ Help with RF433 / RF315 Devices ğŸ“»
rf433.description:
There is a lot of information on this subject.  Check out the links section and the Community can lead your journey here. 

ğŸ“¶ [How RF433 Works](https://bit.ly/DrZzsHow433Works) 
ğŸ“¶ [Flashing the RFBridge](https://bit.ly/DrZzsFlashRFBridgeTasmota) 
ğŸ“¶ [DrZzs Video](https://youtu.be/OfSbIFIJPuc) 
ğŸ“¶ [Digiblur Video](https://youtu.be/w_CchtI-oK0) 
ğŸ“¶ [WhatAreWeFixing.Today Video](https://whatarewefixing.today/?p=134) 
ğŸ“¶ [Multiple sensor setup](https://bit.ly/DrZzsRFBridgeMultiSensorSetup) 
ğŸ“¶ [RM3 & RM4 Broadlink programming from Everything Smart Home](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jEOyTGaKwaQ&t=184s) 

The 433 mhz RF (radio frequency) band and the 315 mhz RF band, depending on the country you live in, is designated for the same purpose. Low power RF transmitters are allowed to broadcast within these frequency ranges. These small transmitters are usually binary type sensors because only a small message is able to be transmitted during an event. Door/Window sensors, PIR sensors, push button transmitters, remote controls and the like are the typical devices using these frequencies. There needs to be a receiver nearby to pick up these signals and act on the message received.

Devices such as the [Itead RFBridge](http://drzzs.com/RF_Bridge) and the [Bond Bridge](https://bit.ly/DrZzsBondBridge) act as reciever hubs to collect data from these sensors and feed the data back to a program such as Home Assistant for further action.  With some devices like the [Itead Sonoff Slampher](https://bit.ly/DrZzsSlampher), the device can â€˜pairâ€™ with a matching RF transmitter bought separately and act on the information provided. Devices are not tied to a common standard (like Zwave) which 1, keeps the price very low, but 2, causes incompatibility between manufacturers.

shelly.title: Shelly ğŸ”Œ IOT Switches and Devices
shelly.description:
Shelly products are made in many form factors, and installation instructions differ between devices.  Consult the documentation that arrived with your device for more information.  

ğŸ”Œ [Shelly Cloud](https://shelly.cloud/)  
ğŸ”Œ [Amazon Buy Shelly 1](https://tinyurl.com/drzzs-shellyone)  
ğŸ”Œ [Amazon Buy Shelly 1PM](https://tinyurl.com/drzzs-shellyonepm)  
ğŸ”Œ [Amazon Buy Shelly 2.5](https://tinyurl.com/drzzs-shellytwopointfive)  

Shelly is a European company that manufactures smart home automation products for use in almost every country, many of which are based upon the venerable ESP8266 microcontroller. Shelly's remote relay line-up consists of single, double, and quad relay options, some with and some without power monitoring.  They also manufacture various types of sensors, power monitoring modules, and RGBW LED controllers.

The stock firmware can be used with the Shelly app along with a HACS integration in Home Assistant, or it can be set up to use a local MQTT Server -- no flashing is required!  If one does not wish to use the stock firmware, most of their products can be flashed with Tasmota, ESPHome, or other custom firmware.

**CAUTION**
Most Shelly devices are used in conjunction with Mains voltages and can be very hazardous if mishandled.

sonoff.title: Sonoff ğŸ”Œ IOT Switches and Devices
sonoff.description:
Sonoff products are made in many form factors, and installation instructions differ between devices.  Consult the documentation that arrived with your device for more information.  

ğŸ”Œ [Sonoff Official Homepage](https://sonoff.tech/)  
ğŸ”Œ [Amazon Buy Sonoff Basic](https://tinyurl.com/drzzs-sonoffbasic)  
ğŸ”Œ [Amazon Buy Sonoff Mini](https://tinyurl.com/drzzs-sonoffmini)  
ğŸ”Œ [Tasmota Sonoff Basic Docs](https://tasmota.github.io/docs/devices/Sonoff-Basic/)  
ğŸ”Œ [WhatAreWeFixing.Today's Sonoff DIY Mode Linux](https://whatarewefixing.today/589/)  

Sonoff is a brand of smarthome products created by Itead.  They make a wide range of inexpensive smarthome gadgets, many are based upon the venerable ESP8266 microcontroller.

Some of the most popular Sonoff producs are the Sonoff Basic and the Sonoff Mini, but they make a number of smaartplugs, wall switches, and in-wall controllable outlets.

The stock firmware uses an app called eWeLink, which integrates with Home Assistant.  If one does not wish to use the stock firmware, most of their products can be flashed with Tasmota, ESPHome, or other custom firmware.

**CAUTION*
Most Sonoff devices are used in conjunction with Mains voltages and can be very hazardous if mishandled.

sonoffDIY.description:

split_config.description:

ğŸ”€ [Doc and Frenck with a live Demo](https://youtu.be/FfjSA2o_0KA) 

AND if you want to split your scripts up so that the script UI editor works and your files are split, [look here](https://community.home-assistant.io/t/script-editor-and-split-up-files/40459/20) or go into a terminal in HA and do this: ```ln -f /config/scripts.yaml /config/#path_to_your_subfolder/scripts.yaml ``` and in configuration.yaml do this: ```script: !include_dir_merge_named /config/#path_to_your_subfolder```.  Then put your split folders here for scripts.

tasmota.title: Tasmota ğŸ”Œ Open source firmware for ESP8266 devices
tasmota.description:
To learn more about flashing tasmota onto your supported device, check out this article: ğŸ”Œ https://tasmota.github.io/docs/Getting-Started/  

ğŸ”Œ [Current Release Change Notes](https://tasmota.github.io/docs/)  
ğŸ”Œ [Tasmota Peripherals](https://tasmota.github.io/docs/Supported-Peripherals/)  
ğŸ”Œ [Tasmota Commands](https://tasmota.github.io/docs/Commands/)  
ğŸ”Œ [All Tasmota Releases](https://github.com/arendst/Tasmota/releases)  
ğŸ”Œ [Tasmota Over-The-Air Download](http://ota.tasmota.com/tasmota/release/)  
ğŸ”Œ [Tasmota Special Binaries](https://github.com/tasmota/binaries)  
ğŸ”Œ [Tasmota Templates](https://templates.blakadder.com/)  

Tasmota is a firmware that can be flashed onto ESP8266 & ESP32 based products and was created by Theo Arends.  It was originally used for Sonoff boards, but quickly snowballed to include *most* ESP MCU chips.  You can use it to control just about everything that you want (plugs, switches, dimmers, bulbs, et cetera).

The reason you'd load this firmware onto your devices is to keep your smart item traffic local to your premise, and not sending it to the cloud servers.  (So that when the internet goes out, your stuff still works correctly).

Tasmota is 100% free and open source making it a great product for the home automation community.

The community submits configuration templates for devices to a site maintained by a user named Blakadder, so most things are pretty easy to configure.  If you run across a new product without a template, you will need to work out where things like LEDs, relays, and the like are by adjusting template settings manually -- but once you've got it, you can submit it to the repository!.

Blakadder's team also maintains a 'naughty list' of devices that are not compatible.

tasmota_upgrade.title: Tasmota Upgrade Path
tasmota_upgrade.description:
To upgrade your Tasmota firmware, you need to follow the path, or risk bad things happening.

 [More information](https://tasmota.github.io/docs/Upgrading/)

template_lights.title: ğŸ§© Tasmota Light Templates in Home Assistant ğŸ§©
template_lights.description:
Building light templates from scratch can be a bit puzzling. ğŸ˜• 
Here is an article from Blakadder explaining the options and requirements from basic to advanced with great examples. 
I have also includes other information about Light Templates and Templating in general. 

ğŸ§© [Tasmota Lights in Home Assistant Using Template Schema](https://blakadder.com/template_schema_lights/) 
ğŸ§© [Home Assistant Template Lights - Official Docs](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/light.template/) 
ğŸ§© [Video from: 'Will Surridge Tech' explaining HA Templates in general](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lPKiCjifX5w)

tips.title: BOT Wrangling 101 on DrZzs Discord
tips.description:
There is a whole reference library in here to help you sort out things.  All contributions are from people on the channel.  

Type `{prefix}reflist` in the chat and you see the list.  Then (tilde) {prefix}topic will bring up that topic.  Also you can type `{prefix}commands` and get a list of BOT commands you nave access to.  

We tend to go to <#717069963357323326> channel to activate those things so as to not fill up the topic channels with info just for you.

troubleshooting.title: Troubleshooting Your HA Configuration Problems
troubleshooting.description: If you're having problems with your updates to your configuration, check the troubleshooting steps in <https://home-assistant.io/docs/configuration/troubleshooting/>

tuya.title: Tuya ğŸ”Œ Proprietary firmware for ESP8266 devices
tuya.description:
Installation instructions vary from item to item.  

ğŸ”Œ [DrZzs YT Video Home Assistant Tuya Integration](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bVa6Yw1gCP0&t=1s)  
ğŸ”Œ [DrZzs Live stream | Flashing Tasmota on Tuya](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=av84uORLB9Y)  
ğŸ”Œ [HA Official Tuya Integration Docs](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/tuya/)  
ğŸ”Œ [KPeyanski's Tuya HA Tutorial](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9E7QMz92aOI)  
ğŸ”Œ [Tuya Homepage](https://www.tuya.com/)  

Tuya is a company that makes a wide array of smart items including smart plugs, wall switches, and dimmers. Their main business is white-label manufacturing for other companies (be it just the chips, or the entire product), so you'll find Tuya devices sold under many different labels (Martin Jerry and Gosund are a couple).  Usually the product pages on retailer's websites will say that the devices work with Amazon's and Google's voice assistant platforms.

See also:  {prefix}TuyaConvert

tuya_convert.title: Tuya Convert
tuya_convert.description:
To see instructions on getting started with Tuya Convert & the links here. 

ğŸ˜ [Tuya Convert Github](https://github.com/ct-Open-Source/tuya-convert) 
ğŸ˜ [Digiblur's Tuya Convert Flash Tuya Devices YT Video](https://youtu.be/dt5-iZc4_qU) 
ğŸ˜ [Tasmota Templates](https://templates.blakadder.com/) 

Tuya convert is an exploit that attacks certain versions of Tuya firmware in order to replace the firmware with something we want.  The current release of the Tuya firmware has an encryption that prevents the exploit, so it works on fewer and fewer products currently being sold.  If someone can figure out the password....   Or someone at the factory would leak it, this may work again.  At this point only new-old-stock items that have not been used in the Tuya App might work.  Sadly most items will not and None that have been used in the Tuya App will convert.

THEREFORE......

Don't be shocked when the Tuya Convert doesn't work for you.  The man-in-the-middle attack that Tuys Convert was against Tuya Firmware has been patched by Tuya, and will likely not help you. 

Find a way to use the device as is, or find way to take the device apart and flash with a serial adapter.

twitchSub.title: Twitch Subscription
twitchSub.description:
To receive the twitch sub role, you **MUST** be a subscriber to the DrZzz's Twitch Channel.  This is **100% Free** if you have Amazon Prime. 

Find out more about [Twitch Prime Here](https://www.twitch.tv/subs/drzzs)  
[Visit DrZzz's Twitch Channel](https://www.twitch.tv/drzzs)  

**Please remember to link your discord account to twitch to receive this role.**  
[->Twitch Integration Help link<-](https://support.discordapp.com/hc/en-us/articles/212112068-Twitch-Integration-FAQ) Scroll down to the `For Viewers` section.  

Note: The Twitch subscriber roles are updated every hour automatically, so be patient...

wled.title: WLED - LED light controller firmware.
wled.description:
Check out this link to get started: 

ğŸš¥ [WLED FAQ](https://kno.wled.ge/basics/faq/)  

WLED is a firmware that can be loaded onto ESP8266 and ESP32 microcontrollers, such as the Dig-Uno and Dig-Quad, and is used to control addressable LEDs. 
WLED has many built-in features, has an app for convenient conrol, is compatible with Home Assistant via an integration, DMX-based Light Controller protocols, and can be used with xLights for advanced lighting effects.

[WLED Discord](https://discord.gg/hyAzVMASsu)
[WLED App on Google Play Store](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.aircoookie.WLED)
[WLED App on Apple App Store](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/wled/id1475695033)

See also: 
 {prefix}NeoPixel
 {prefix}wled_update 

[Sound Reactive WLED WIKI](https://github.com/atuline/WLED/wiki) 
[WLED Latest Release](https://github.com/Aircoookie/WLED/releases/latest)

wled_update.description:
Connect your WLED Controller to your computer and use this site to easily install the latest WLED firmware version. 

ğŸš¥ [WLED Update](https://install.wled.me/v2.htm)

zigbee.title: Zigbee Wireless Mesh Protocol
zigbee.description:
Zigbee requires a hub to communicate so be sure to have one ready!  

ğŸ [Amazon Buy ConBee II](https://www.amazon.com/dresden-elektronik-ConBee-Universal-Gateway/dp/B07PZ7ZHG5/)  
ğŸ [List of approved Zigbee2MQTT Adapters](https://www.zigbee2mqtt.io/information/supported_adapters.html)  
ğŸ [ZigBee2MQTT Firmware and Installation](https://www.zigbee2mqtt.io/)  
ğŸ [Sonoff Zigbee & ZHA HA Integration](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xc_HGvrOxp8)  
ğŸ [Blakadder's ZigBee Page](https://zigbee.blakadder.com/)  
ğŸ [ZigBee Alliance Homepage](https://zigbeealliance.org/zigbee_products/)  

OH THE ZIGBEE!

Zigbee is a communication protocol that has flourished in the home automation community.  Zigbee is often preferred to Wifi-based technologies due to its low power consumption and long battery life.  The downside to using zigbee is you need to have a HUB to communicate with all of your devices.  In some ways this is advantageous as it requires fewer devices connect to your wifi network.

One zigbee hub that has a high approval is the conbee 2.  It is not the cheapest option, but it is fairly easy to configure.  Another great option is Zigbee2MQTT which will relay zigbee data thru your mqtt broker.  Whichever hub you select, be sure to verify that devices are supported by your hub before buying as most hubs do not support every device.

If nothing else, Zigbee is a very powerful protocol that opens the horizon to many types of sensors, switches, and other types of home automation devices.

ğŸ›‘**CAUTION**ğŸ›‘ Zigbee operates in the 2.4 GHz Spectrum, which is shared with Wifi, Bluetooth, Microwave Ovens, and other things.  If you have a lot of 2.4 GHz at your location, your Zigbee may be unreliable.

pixelheads.description: Have an LED related question?  Be sure to ask your question in <#511947803115913217> Channel here on discord!  Our LED masterminds, the PixelHeads, generally hang out there and can answer your question(s) swiftly.

post it here.title: Ask your question here
post it here.description: It is best to ask general questions in the channel versus DM'ing (Direct message) a user/staff member.  This allows everyone in the channel to help or get information reducing repetitive questions.

quad_pinout.title: Dig-Quad Default Pinout
quad_pinout.description:
The Default Pinout for a Dig-Quad with an ESP32. 

 LED 1 Output = Pin 16 
 LED 2 Output = Pin 3 
 LED 3 Output = Pin 1 
 LED 4 Output = Pin 4 
 LED 5 Output = Pin 15 

 Additional detail is available here: [QuinLed Dig-Quad Pinout Guide](https://quinled.info/quinled-dig-quad-pinout-guide/)

uno_pinout.title: Dig-Uno Default Pinout
uno_pinout.description:
The Default Pinout for a Dig-Uno with an ESP32. 

 LED 1 Output = Pin 16 
 LED 2 Output = Pin 3 

 Additional detail is available here: [QuinLed Dig-Uno Pinout Guide](https://quinled.info/quinled-dig-uno-pinout-guide/)
